thread.title: Storm Doris: Heathrow flights cancelled and trains delayed as 90mph winds wreak havoc across UK
thread.title_full: Storm Doris: Heathrow flights cancelled and trains delayed as 90mph winds wreak havoc across UK

author: Fiona Simpson
title: Storm Doris: Heathrow flights cancelled and trains delayed as 90mph winds wreak havoc across UK
text:
24 GMT Click to followThe Evening Standard Strong gales: Winds of up to 60mph are set to batter the capital Stefan Wermuth/Reuters 
Airline passengers at Heathrow Airport are facing travel chaos today as dozens of flights were cancelled because of Storm Doris. 
Ten per cent of flights out of the airport have been cancelled due to high winds, a spokesman said. 
Other flights are expected to be delayed. 
Winds of nearly 90 mph are expected to batter the UK, with gales of up to 60 mph expected to hit the capital by Thursday evening. 
Doris is likely to damage buildings and send debris flying, the Met Office has said. 
An 87mph gust was recorded at Mace Head on the Galway coast in the Republic of Ireland in the early hours as Doris made its way east. Storm Doris explainer 
The UK was being battered by gales in the early hours, with speeds of 72mph recorded at Aberdaron on the west coast of Wales. 
In Dublin, Twitter users reported flooding being pumped from streets near the Liffey and debris all over the roads. 
46,000 homes across Dublin, Sligo, Galway, Leitrim and Mayo are also without power. 
The storm was already causing carnage yesterday after a tree fell onto a car with a schoolboy inside in Bristol 
Aer Lingus cancelled 12 flights between the UK and the Republic of Ireland in anticipation of the winds as Heathrow warned all customers to check their flights before travelling. 
Network Rail has warned rail passengers of delays and cancellations after imposing speed restrictions for safety reasons. Read more
